executive_summary: Short and concise executive summary (max 500 words). Orthopedic treatments have become one of the largest healthcare spending categories by insurers in the US. An aging population's growing incidence of musculoskeletal conditions is behind higher spending, along with the steep treatment costs associated with joint replacements. In recent years, rising health expenditure, broader public and commercial insurance coverage and disposable incomes have only strengthened spending.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Orthopedists are Critical to Support an Aging Population
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rising incomes, broader access to public and private insurance programs and the aging population's expanding medical needs have led to rapidly rising demand for orthopedists in recent years. Spending on orthopedic care has been one of the fastest-growing shares of national healthcare expenditure.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consolidation Permanently Shifts the Industry's Landscape
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the rising consolidation activity that has been occurring in recent years. Fewer independent, solo practices are operating, with more large group practices emerging. A trend of large group providers combining to become 'supergroups' has also grown.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A HIGHER VOLUME OF MEDICARE PATIENTS WILL INTRODUCE FINANCIAL HEADWINDS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Mounting demand for orthopedic treatment will come from an aging population and older, active adults seeking to prolong their lifestyles. A primary challenge facing orthopedists will be the growing number of Medicare beneficiaries requiring treatment. Declining reimbursements meeting with a higher volume of Medicare patients could financially strain providers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: EVOLVING TECHNOLOGY WILL RESHAPE HOW ORTHOPEDISTS OPERATE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rapidly advancing technology will bring new ways for orthopedists to diagnose, treat and plan care. Main areas spurring change will be 3D printing, orthobiologics and artificial intelligence (AI). 3D printing will become easier and cheaper, making it a more feasible option for orthopedists to integrate into offices.

industry_definition: Orthopedists are medical doctors specializing in the treatment of injuries and diseases affecting the musculoskeletal system.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid
threats: Number of people with private health insurance

key_trends: Stringent regulations safeguard patient's safety and security. Orthopedic practices must stay compliant or risk facing serious financial and legal consequences.
Insurers influence what orthopaedists earn annually. Physicians can exert some influence in negotiations with private insurers, but reimbursements from public insurers are predetermined.

Consolidation activity shifts the industry's makeup. While an uptick in group practices and private equity interest has permanently changed the landscape, no single orthopedic controls the broader industry.
Educational requirements limit substitutes for a specialist physician
Demand for joint replacements has reached an unprecedented high
Private insurers are the largest payers of orthopedic treatment
Orthopaedics' massive share of healthcare expenditure elicits federal assistance
Orthopaedists are one of the highest-paid specialties
Rising spending on orthopedic care supports profit growth

market_segmentation.segment_description: Private insurance providers are the largest payers of orthopedic treatments. According to McKinsey, orthopedic care was the largest spending category for beneficiaries of employer-based insurance in 2021. Private insurance plans often reimburse healthcare providers at higher rates than Medicaid or Medicare. Higher reimbursements allow orthopedists to receive more revenue for the services they provide.

Reimbursements from public insurers (Medicare, Medicaid) are the second-largest revenue source for orthopedists. While musculoskeletal conditions can occur at any age, adults 65 and older are at the highest risk of developing them. As the population ages and more adults gain Medicare eligibility, orthopedists have treated more Medicare beneficiaries. A rising volume of Medicare patients hasn't translated to an equal increase in Medicare reimbursements. In recent years, declining reimbursements from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) have pressured some providers to drop or limit Medicare patients.

products_and_services.product_description: Two of the largest areas for orthopedists in the US are joint replacement and spinal conditions.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: AN AGING POPULATION TRANSLATES TO HIGHER SPENDING ON
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Two of the largest areas for orthopedists in the US are joint replacement and spinal conditions. An aging population is mainly responsible for this. Degenerative conditions like osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis are more common in adults 65 and over, leading to higher demand for joint replacements from this demographic. Spinal disorders are also more prevalent in older adults.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: SPORTS MEDICINE IS A FAST-GROWING AREA
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The mounting popularity of fitness, wellness and prevention supports demand. Increasing participation in sports by children is also driving growth in this subspecialty.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Rising incomes have supported consumers' interest in sports medicine
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Rising incomes have supported consumers' interest in sports medicine. Seeking out nonessential orthopedic care isn't always covered by insurance, so higher incomes allow patients to cover out-of-pocket costs.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand for sports medicine isn't expected to subside moving forward
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for sports medicine isn't expected to subside moving forward. The popularity of active lifestyles across age groups will continue to bring more patients in.

top_companies.company_name: There are no major players in this industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Orthopaedic workforce can't keep pace with demand
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Chronic staffing shortages occurring across the healthcare sector haven't spared orthopaedic practices. The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated hiring challenges occurring prior to 2020. A preexisting undersupply of orthopaedists met with rising demand from an aging population is driving physician shortages. A shrinking nurse workforce – an outcome of pandemic stress and burn out – has left health systems nationwide cumbering for RNs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Specialist physicians, including orthopedists, have historically resisted economic fluctuations. As specialists, no other medical professional or service can directly substitute for an orthopedist.

Musculoskeletal system (MSK) diseases can occur regardless of a person's economic standing or employment status, shielding the industry from volatility. An aging population's rising rates of MSK conditions grow the patient population, limiting volatility further.

FAQs.question: What is the regulation level in the industry?
FAQs.answer: The regulation level is described as high and steady.

FAQs.question: What is the level of industry assistance?
FAQs.answer: The level of industry assistance is described as moderate and steady.
